title: Do the medical helicopters get shot down when attempting to rescue soldiers at war? - Quora

response.answer_text: Whenever possible. Beginning in the Korean War and ever since. The ability and demonstrated intention of a military force to extract its forces when injured or facing massacre has always been a morale boost. Denying your adversary the ability to treat and/or evacuate wounded troops from combat has always best served enemies. Especially since WWII, the concept of wounding your enemy rather than killing him outright was considered optimal if possible. If you kill a soldier, he’s just dead. If you wound him, he’s lying on the ground screaming for help, something his colleagues can hear quite clearly. If they try to rescue him, you get to shoot them too. If they send in medics, unarmed by agreement and clearly badged with large red crosses as “noncombatants” and you shoot them, too, that simply reinforces the terror in the ranks of your enemies. If you fast forward and that rescue and medical evacuation is coming from unarmed medical evacuation helicopters and you can shoot them down, too, even better! Don’t throw rhetoric at me about the Geneva Convention. Very few conflicts since the end of WWII have involved the sort of combat in which they would apply and those conventions have never been implemented enthusiastically. My father was a medic in George Patton’s 4th Armored Division in WWII. He told me the Germans shot at medics so often, he took to carrying a .45 caliber Colt pistol. Completely unauthorized and probably meaningless in a combat zone ruled by high powered rifles and machine guns, but it gave him some moral confidence that he wasn’t completely defenseless. If he’d been much younger and had flown on medivac helicopters in Vietnam, it’s likely that he’d have done the same since the enemies he would have been facing treated helicopter pilots and crews exceptionally poorly when they had the chance to shoot them down.
Absolutely. Take MJ Hegar as a good example:  Hell, it is the plot of the whole movie “Courage Under Fire”—though MJ was real.  That bright red cross on the door is just a target.
